information.title: Definition
information.description: Fundamental Rights are basic human rights guaranteed to all citizens by the Constitution. They are essential for the overall development of individuals and are enforceable by law.

information.title: Right to Equality
information.description: This right ensures that all citizens are equal before the law. It prohibits discrimination based on religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth. It also abolishes untouchability and provides for equal opportunities in public employment.

information.title: Right to Freedom
information.description: The Right to Freedom includes several freedoms such as freedom of speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, and the right to practice any profession. However, reasonable restrictions can be imposed on these freedoms for the interest of public order, security, and morality.

information.title: Right Against Exploitation
information.description: This right prohibits all forms of forced labor, child labor, and human trafficking. It protects citizens from exploitation and ensures human dignity.

information.title: Right to Freedom of Religion
information.description: This right allows citizens to practice, profess, and propagate any religion of their choice. It also prohibits the state from imposing any particular religion and ensures secularism.

information.title: Cultural and Educational Rights
information.description: These rights protect the interests of minorities. They allow minorities to preserve their language, script, and culture. Minorities also have the right to establish and administer their own educational institutions.

information.title: Right to Constitutional Remedies
information.description: This right allows citizens to approach the courts if their fundamental rights are violated. It ensures that people can seek justice if their rights are infringed upon.
